great-room-1.description: This talk will cover all the basic steps you need to perform in order to go from zero to working conversation with Google Assistant.
great-room-1.name: Conversation Actions for Google Assistant

great-room-2.description:
You can never really know just how secure your app is until you've done your best trying to break it.

In a world where building apps is similar to playing with Legos, the sturdiness and stability of our creations is mostly tested by others. Unfortunately, this places our users at risk of exposing their data into potentially harmful hands.

Let's dive together and explore a series of practical, hands-on examples on how to explore an app, dismantle it and alter it in a way it wasn't intended to be.
great-room-2.name: Break your app before someone else does

great-room-1.description: Accessibility often isn't a priority for companies as they grow, but if you don't invest in it early it can become a knotty problem.  In this talk I will discuss breaking down a complex Android application to find low-hanging fixes as well as prioritizing larger improvements and investing in accessibility in the future.  We will discuss my experience growing grassroots support for accessibility improvements at Pinterest and both the moral and business value of improving it.
great-room-1.name: Accessibility @ Scale

great-room-2.description:
Google Cardboard has been around since Google I/O 2014. It is by far the most affordable, and possibly most clever VR viewer out there today. To develop for Google Cardboard, the popular 3d game engine, Unity can be used. 

This presentation will cover the  basics of developing in Unity for Google Cardboard including:
• What is Unity and how to develop 3d apps using it.
• How to develop for Google Cardboard in a Unity project.
• Best practices for developing for Google Cardboard.
great-room-2.name: I Like The Way You Move

great-room-1.description:
We’ve all been there: you have an app with outdated technology, and you know you should update it. But the legacy code is complicated and opaque, and due to support issues, you can’t just use the new library in the straightforward way the code samples show it. But perf gains and code clarity are on the line, so you need to find a way to make it work.

Well, you’re in luck! This talk is for you, person who’s trying to make it work. Drawing from examples encountered with Pinterest’s own transition to Retrofit, we’ll explore ways to retrofit Retrofit onto an existing networking layer while balancing the interests of hundreds of millions of users relying on a performant app. Ranging from big wins to unsightly mistakes, this tour will be both a cringeworthy and infinitely practical look at what happens when you can’t start from scratch.
great-room-1.name: Retrofitting Retrofit

great-room-2.description:
Exciting times for mixed reality enthusiasts. With many AR and VR platforms now available, we're witnessing the birth of a new medium. 

In many ways, this boom is similar to the personal computer revolution of the 70s and 80s. People are wondering: "Besides games, what are these gadgets good for, anyway?"

In this session, we'll see how people are using mixed reality for social good. Then, we'll learn about the Tango and Daydream platforms from Google. We'll use these and other platforms to build our own mixed reality experience.
great-room-2.name: Mixed Reality for Social Good

great-room-1.description: Nearby is a proximity API, allowing your apps to detect and communicate with other devices around them. This talk will describe how the Nearby API can be used in your app to detect other devices and communicate with them. It'll provide an introduction to the Nearby APIs, and give an insight into best practices for adding proximity features to your app. The target audience are app developers who want to explore how communication with nearby devices can provide magical user experiences in their apps.
great-room-1.name: Contextualize Apps with Nearby + Awareness

great-room-2.description:
Mentoring and onboarding new engineers is one of the most important things you
can do to grow your team.  Effective and intentional mentoring decreases the number of bugs shipped to the Play Store, improves the quality of your application, and helps keep code standards high as your team grows and changes.


Yet for all of its importance, there is hardly any information about how to mentor effectively.  There are many resources about how engineers can get 4% productivity gains by learning new Android Studio shortcuts, but there are almost none about how they can get 400% productivity gains for their team by helping other developers be more productive.


In this talk, I'll discuss how to think about mentoring Android engineers from the ground-up.  First, we’ll discuss how to structure a plan for your mentee such that they move from “What’s an ADB?” to “Let’s use Retrofit, RxJava, and Dagger to make a testable app with MVP architecture” in no-time flat.  Next, we’ll talk about how to interact with your mentee such that every challenge helps them level-up their development skills and build your team culture.  Lastly, we’ll discuss how you can use your experience as a mentor to improve your own engineering skills.
great-room-2.name: Write Less Code and Get More Done: Multiplying Your Impact Through Mentorship

a-healthy-dose-of-gradle.description:
Gradle is the official build system for Android but few ever go beyond editing dependencies or copy-pasting code from stackoverflow. However, it is possible to have a build that is both fast and tailored to your needs.

This session aims to make you a better developer by taking back control of your build.  

We will be covering concepts like the build phases (Initialization, Configuration, Execution), the task graph and the plugins that are available for you. We will look at how to extend an existing build by creating custom tasks, developing our own simple plugins and learning how to debug and test them. And since no one likes a slow build, we will use the Gradle Profiler to troubleshoot performance problems and talk about the usual root causes for neverending builds.
a-healthy-dose-of-gradle.name: A Healthy Dose of Gradle

accessibility-at-scale.description: Accessibility often isn't a priority for companies as they grow, but if you don't invest in it early it can become a knotty problem.  In this talk I will discuss breaking down a complex Android application to find low-hanging fixes as well as prioritizing larger improvements and investing in accessibility in the future.  We will discuss my experience growing grassroots support for accessibility improvements at Pinterest and both the moral and business value of improving it.
accessibility-at-scale.name: Accessibility @ Scale

advanced-android-touches.description:
For developers working with custom views and touches for the first time, it could be hard to decipher what goes on when a user touches the screen. In this talk we’ll trace through the steps to see how Android decides which view should handle a touch. We’ll visually examine how a view hierarchy is laid out and examine the multiple methods that are involved when handling touches. Lastly, we’ll look into the different kinds of touches that are categorized in Android and when the system finally decides the action is a 'touch'. 

To wrap up the talk, we’ll look at an example of a custom translucent bottom bar laid over a recycler view. Using our newfound knowledge on touches, we’ll modify the navigation bar to handle different scenarios (such as scrolls, and clicking on a icon) so it can know when to handle a touch event, and when it should pass the event to the recycler view behind it.
advanced-android-touches.name: Advanced Android Touches

android-auto-driving-the-future.name: Android Auto - Driving the Future

break-your-app-before-someone-else-does.description:
You can never really know just how secure your app is until you've done your best trying to break it.

In a world where building apps is similar to playing with Legos, the sturdiness and stability of our creations is mostly tested by others. Unfortunately, this places our users at risk of exposing their data into potentially harmful hands.

Let's dive together and explore a series of practical, hands-on examples on how to explore an app, dismantle it and alter it in a way it wasn't intended to be.
break-your-app-before-someone-else-does.name: Break your app before someone else does

building-a-modern-android-ui.description:
Expectations for what makes a good mobile UI increased drastically in recent years, notably with the introduction of Material Design.
Yet, it's not always clear (or easy) how to achieve such results. This talk will cover how to take advantage of existing libraries
(support lib, constraintlayout), technics (animations, vector drawables) and tools (android studio) in order to craft a modern UI.
building-a-modern-android-ui.name: Building a Modern Android UI

building-gradle-plugins.description: From simple tricks such as adding a git SHA to their application's version name to complex processes such as generating type-safe code from SQL files, Gradle and its plugins are powerful tools that can help developers automate and simplify their build and release process. I will go through the process of writing a simple task in Gradle to pulling it out and turning it into its own Gradle plugin.
building-gradle-plugins.name: Building Gradle Plugins

contextualize-apps-with-nearby-awareness.description: Nearby is a proximity API, allowing your apps to detect and communicate with other devices around them. This talk will describe how the Nearby API can be used in your app to detect other devices and communicate with them. It'll provide an introduction to the Nearby APIs, and give an insight into best practices for adding proximity features to your app. The target audience are app developers who want to explore how communication with nearby devices can provide magical user experiences in their apps.
contextualize-apps-with-nearby-awareness.name: Contextualize Apps with Nearby + Awareness

conversation-actions-for-google-assistan.description: This talk will cover all the basic steps you need to perform in order to go from zero to working conversation with Google Assistant.
conversation-actions-for-google-assistan.name: Conversation Actions for Google Assistant

cool-constraint-layout.description:
ConstraintLayout is the newest layout on the Android platform. While it’s often compared directly with RelativeLayout in terms of functionality and performance. However, it actually possesses many features and ways of building layouts, even if you don’t count the shiny new features. But since it’s so new, you may not have heard of all of them yet.

In this session we will look at some examples of cool things that you can do with ConstraintLayout to more easily build complex layouts and transitions, focusing on features unique to ConstraintLayout.
cool-constraint-layout.name: Cool Constraint Layout

coordinating-space-and-time.description:
One of Android's core requirements is that the UI runs on the main thread and IO in the background. Though concurrency is powerful, it's also frustrating to deal with forking threads.

In this talk we'll:

U+23F0 Learn how smartphone CPUs contradict your memory.
U+23F0 Discuss how Android's compilers disregard your orders.
U+23F0 Sync up on Java's concurrency APIs.
⏰ See how to make sexy apps that aren't racy.
U+23F0 Determine if reactive programming is the future.

This talk covers a sequence of concurrency topics. Attendees will be able to fix volatile programs and block threading bugs before they happen.
coordinating-space-and-time.name: Coordinating Space and Time

dagger-2.description:
Dagger 2 is Google’s solution for dependency injection on Android. It powers some of the largest and most successful applications from Google and others, but applying it has been fraught with ambiguity and ad hoc solutions that require a lot of up-front engineering.

In an effort to make it viable for more projects, the Dagger team at Google has focused specifically on creating new features, libraries and well-documented patterns for using Dagger 2 in an Android application. The result is a structure that allows Android applications to be modular, testable, and performant with minimal boilerplate and infrastructure.

This is an overview of what has been added, how it was designed and how to apply it. Attendees should leave with a clear understanding the benefits of dependency injection in an Android app and how Dagger 2 can help realize those benefits most simply and effectively.
dagger-2.name: Dagger 2 on Android

design-develop-deploy.description:
Previously at DramaFever (a Warner Bros. company), designers and developers focused mostly on their own tasks without the consideration of how it would affect each other - the ones designing an app and the ones eventually building it. Although we have an iterative process in place, we found ourselves repeating some of the work while working on several projects. 

With our team growing and projects needing to be output faster, we decided to streamline our Android design and development process and would love to share this with all of you!

In this talk, we will walk you through our process of how to:
1. Find common ground with your designer or developer
2. Ship apps faster if you do the legwork beforehand 
3. Design an app from a developer’s perspective as a designer
4. Implement designs to be more performant and responsive from the developer’s end

This talk is aimed at designers and developers.
design-develop-deploy.name: Design Develop Deploy!

from-interactions-to-insights.description:
In 2016 Firebase 2.0 was released, providing a "backend as a service" that extended beyond development features to also providing tools for user engagement and monetization. With mobile app markets becoming more crowded, developers increasingly need such tools to differentiate their products and engage (and retain) their users' attention.

In this talk, I will provide a brief overview of Firebase before doing a deep-dive into Firebase Analytics, a core component that powers many of these features. With Analytics, the developer can instrument the application to gather user behavior information and view valuable insights about individual and collective engagement. They can then use those insights to drive automated actions or prioritize development decisions in an educated manner. 

The first half of this talk will focus on the Firebase API (front-end integration) for Android, focusing specifically on instrumenting data capture. The second half of the talk will focus on the Firebase Dashboard (back-end visualization) and explore the rich set of insights and configuration options available to developers, using a real dataset. 
The goal of the talk is to demonstrate the ease and utility of Firebase Analytics for mobile development, and also emphasize its value as a common and consistent back-end for cross-platform development.
from-interactions-to-insights.name: From Interactions To Insights: Data-Driven Development with Firebase Analytics

graphics-programming-for-non-graphics-pr.description: Most Android programmers have had encounters with the Android 2D rendering API, Canvas. This API is just one of the many techniques used for real-time and offline rendering on desktop, consoles and mobile devices. In this talk, we'll go through a tour of the various rendering techniques used nowadays: vector graphics, path tracing, signed-distance fields, rasterized 3D (and its various lighting mechanisms), etc.
graphics-programming-for-non-graphics-pr.name: Graphics Programming for Non-Graphics Programmers

i-like-the-way-you-move.description:
Google Cardboard has been around since Google I/O 2014. It is by far the most affordable, and possibly most clever VR viewer out there today. To develop for Google Cardboard, the popular 3d game engine, Unity can be used. 

This presentation will cover the  basics of developing in Unity for Google Cardboard including:
• What is Unity and how to develop 3d apps using it.
• How to develop for Google Cardboard in a Unity project.
• Best practices for developing for Google Cardboard.
i-like-the-way-you-move.name: I Like The Way You Move

just-android-things.description: Google recently announced the public developer preview of Android Things, a platform that brings the power of Android development to embedded and IoT devices. Android developers can use the Android SDK, Google services, and development tools they are familiar with to get up and running quickly. Android Things also brings a suite of new APIs to developers to help their apps better integrate with the hardware and the core operating system. In this talk, you will learn why Android Things exists, where it is supported, and how to get started with development.
just-android-things.name: Just Android Things...

kotlin-uncovered.description: Kotlin does a lot for us in the way of reducing boilerplate. But what is it really doing? We will be inspecting some decompiled Kotlin to discover how it does its job. By looking underneath at how it handles data classes, lambdas, and delegation, we can better understand how the language executes what we write. If you’re curious about the language, or already using it in production, you should walk away from this investigation with a deeper understanding of Kotlin, and some tools for continued exploration.
kotlin-uncovered.name: Kotlin: Uncovered

mixed-reality-for-social-good.description:
Exciting times for mixed reality enthusiasts. With many AR and VR platforms now available, we're witnessing the birth of a new medium. 

In many ways, this boom is similar to the personal computer revolution of the 70s and 80s. People are wondering: "Besides games, what are these gadgets good for, anyway?"

In this session, we'll see how people are using mixed reality for social good. Then, we'll learn about the Tango and Daydream platforms from Google. We'll use these and other platforms to build our own mixed reality experience.
mixed-reality-for-social-good.name: Mixed Reality for Social Good

retrofitting-retrofit.description:
We’ve all been there: you have an app with outdated technology, and you know you should update it. But the legacy code is complicated and opaque, and due to support issues, you can’t just use the new library in the straightforward way the code samples show it. But perf gains and code clarity are on the line, so you need to find a way to make it work.

Well, you’re in luck! This talk is for you, person who’s trying to make it work. Drawing from examples encountered with Pinterest’s own transition to Retrofit, we’ll explore ways to retrofit Retrofit onto an existing networking layer while balancing the interests of hundreds of millions of users relying on a performant app. Ranging from big wins to unsightly mistakes, this tour will be both a cringeworthy and infinitely practical look at what happens when you can’t start from scratch.
retrofitting-retrofit.name: Retrofitting Retrofit

rxjava-2-for-the-rest-of-us.description:
The Reactive Extensions for the JVM, better known as RxJava, have become a popular tool in Android development over the past years. Many new and existing libraries added support for Rx and “reactive” solutions to existing problems popped up over time. RxJava is both known for it’s power and it’s steep learning curve, so if you aren’t using RxJava already, what are you missing out on? Should you even be using RxJava?

In this talk we’ll go over what RxJava is and how you can use it to solve problems in your Android apps, one step at a time. We will discuss how you can prevent shooting yourself in the foot by looking at common mistakes you may make when using RxJava and discussing tips and tricks for keeping your reactive app manageable.
rxjava-2-for-the-rest-of-us.name: RxJava 2 for the Rest of Us

understanding-material-design.description:
It's been over 2 years since Material Design was released, yet there's still a wide variety of misconceptions out there in the community. In this talk, I'll perform a deep dive into the guidelines, what they actually mean, and ultimately, talk about what is Material and what isn't.

This is related to my popular Medium series: https://raveesh.in/understanding-material-design-7991b1469a63
understanding-material-design.name: Understanding Material Design

websocket-to-me.description: In a world of constant location updates, real time web, and chat bots, WebSockets have become increasingly common. Recently OkHttp 3.5 included native support for WebSockets and but other libraries have had support for some time. This talk will cover some possible use cases of WebSockets, how to integrate WebSockets into your project, and compare the features of OkHttp with other libraries.
websocket-to-me.name: WebSocket to Me!

whats-new-in-firebase.description: Join this session to find out how the Firebase platform has expanded and what it means for your total application architecture.
whats-new-in-firebase.name: What's new in Firebase

where-i-find-stairs-tango.description:
Join Shan Motlani and Valerie Scarlata will introduce you to Angular 2 and lead you through a codelab with Angular 2 and Firebase
We'll go over...
- What has changed in Angular 2 vs. Angular 1.x
- Using TypeScript to code faster and safer
- The building blocks of Angular 2 Apps - Components, Services and Directives
Then we will walk you through the development flow of an Angular 2 app by building one that integrates Firebase.
where-i-find-stairs-tango.name: Where I find stairs, Tango?

write-less-code-and-get-more-done.description:
Mentoring and onboarding new engineers is one of the most important things you
can do to grow your team.  Effective and intentional mentoring decreases the number of bugs shipped to the Play Store, improves the quality of your application, and helps keep code standards high as your team grows and changes.


Yet for all of its importance, there is hardly any information about how to mentor effectively.  There are many resources about how engineers can get 4% productivity gains by learning new Android Studio shortcuts, but there are almost none about how they can get 400% productivity gains for their team by helping other developers be more productive.


In this talk, I'll discuss how to think about mentoring Android engineers from the ground-up.  First, we’ll discuss how to structure a plan for your mentee such that they move from “What’s an ADB?” to “Let’s use Retrofit, RxJava, and Dagger to make a testable app with MVP architecture” in no-time flat.  Next, we’ll talk about how to interact with your mentee such that every challenge helps them level-up their development skills and build your team culture.  Lastly, we’ll discuss how you can use your experience as a mentor to improve your own engineering skills.
write-less-code-and-get-more-done.name: Write Less Code and Get More Done: Multiplying Your Impact Through Mentorship

2017-04-20.description: Welcoming everyone to Windy City DevCon and thanking our sponsors.
2017-04-20.name: Break your app before someone else does

2017-04-20.description: This presentation will provide an overview of the platform including a few demos of key products within GCP.
2017-04-20.name: Accessibility @ Scale

2017-04-20.description:
Google Cardboard has been around since Google I/O 2014. It is by far the most affordable, and possibly most clever VR viewer out there today. To develop for Google Cardboard, the popular 3d game engine, Unity can be used. 

This presentation will cover the  basics of developing in Unity for Google Cardboard including:
• What is Unity and how to develop 3d apps using it.
• How to develop for Google Cardboard in a Unity project.
• Best practices for developing for Google Cardboard.
2017-04-20.name: I Like The Way You Move

2017-04-20.description: Hands on Firebase demo and talk
2017-04-20.name: Retrofitting Retrofit

2017-04-20.description: A deep dive into the world of animation in Material Design. We'll cover what Material Design is, how natural motion plays a role in its principles and how to create meaningful animations that exhibit the essence of Material Design strives for.
2017-04-20.name: Mixed Reality for Social Good

2017-04-20.description: So you want to start a DevOps revolution. Great...where do you start? Going from manual deployments to a fully automated delivery pipeline has brought many changes; both technical and cultural. In this talk, we will cover "the five phases of DevOps" we found on our journey at Gogo. Finally, we will wrap up the talk with how you too can start your own DevOps revolution including some tool demos and examples.
2017-04-20.name: Contextualize Apps with Nearby + Awareness

2017-04-20.description: Have you seen Cloud Spin? It's a demo that Google Cloud Developer Advocates (Ray Tsang, Bret McGowen, and Francesc Campoy) developed for the Google Cloud Platform Next event series. The demo, consists of 19 Nexus 6 cameras that were placed around a half-circle pointing inwards to take a picture of the subject at the same moment in time, to create a 180 degree animated GIF - see them at @googlecloudspin twitter! But wait, the Android cameras introduces some unknown delays when taking a photo - how did we make all the cameras take pictures at the same time? What did we use to process and stitch the photos together? And most importantly, how did we pull it off in a matter of 3 weeks? Join this session to learn more about what we did behind the scenes, and how we leveraged open source technology, Google Cloud Platform, and Firebase to help us develop the demo rapidly.
2017-04-20.name: Write Less Code and Get More Done: Multiplying Your Impact Through Mentorship

2017-04-20.description: The Firebase Database lets you synchronize data between clients in real time, which is perfect for building multi-player games. In this talk I will describe a collaborative web-based sci-fi game I built using Firebase, what I learned along the way and how it made me a better dad.
2017-04-20.name: From Interactions To Insights: Data-Driven Development with Firebase Analytics

2017-04-20.description: As developers, you interact with Android system services every day. They expose a host of platform features to applications, but what do you really know about them? In this talk, we will examine the system service architecture that connects applications to device hardware. You will gain a deeper understanding of core platform technologies such as Binder IPC and AIDL, which you can use to tune how your applications interact with the platform.
2017-04-20.name: WebSocket to Me!

2017-04-20.description:
Starting a new Android app is always exciting: you have the opportunity to create an awesome app from zero... but it is also a lot of responsibility! Any step in the wrong direction might turn your new app into a disaster. 
You need the right people on your team, you need the right technology and you need the proper setup.
Sounds easy, uh? Well... it's not! Many apps did not survive even this first step. Let me help you to identify the key elements to help your Android team succeed.
2017-04-20.name: Just Android Things...

2017-04-20.description:
What’s the deal with Kotlin? Why would you want to learn a new programming language to write Android apps - isn’t Java good enough? This talk is for those unacquainted with Kotlin, and might teach those who are familiar some new tricks.

This talk will cover:
- Why Kotlin is a good choice for Android Developers
- How to solve problems in more expressive ways with Kotlin’s language features
- Some interesting Kotlin libraries and tools
2017-04-20.name: What's new in Firebase

2017-04-20.description:
Join Shan Motlani and Valerie Scarlata will introduce you to Angular 2 and lead you through a codelab with Angular 2 and Firebase
We'll go over...
- What has changed in Angular 2 vs. Angular 1.x
- Using TypeScript to code faster and safer
- The building blocks of Angular 2 Apps - Components, Services and Directives
Then we will walk you through the development flow of an Angular 2 app by building one that integrates Firebase.
2017-04-20.name: Where I find stairs, Tango?

2017-04-21.description:
Dagger 2 is Google’s solution for dependency injection on Android. It powers some of the largest and most successful applications from Google and others, but applying it has been fraught with ambiguity and ad hoc solutions that require a lot of up-front engineering.

In an effort to make it viable for more projects, the Dagger team at Google has focused specifically on creating new features, libraries and well-documented patterns for using Dagger 2 in an Android application. The result is a structure that allows Android applications to be modular, testable, and performant with minimal boilerplate and infrastructure.

This is an overview of what has been added, how it was designed and how to apply it. Attendees should leave with a clear understanding the benefits of dependency injection in an Android app and how Dagger 2 can help realize those benefits most simply and effectively.
2017-04-21.name: Dagger 2 on Android
RxJava 2 for the Rest of Us

abaotic.bio: During college I got involved in e-learning projects where I developed in Java, and ended up in love with it. After graduation I got a job at Infinum as an Android developer, and have been working there ever since. By the end of 2014. I switched from various projects in the telecommunication, medical and travel industry to mobile banking, where I became the Technical Manager of Mobile Banking in early 2016. My responsibilities include researching new technology and advancements in security, making sure new practices are implemented and generally pushing things forward in the right direction.
abaotic.name: Ana Baotić

akelly.bio: Andrew is a freelance Android Developer based in Sydney Australia. He is also a Google Developer Expert for Android and is one of the organisers of the Sydney Google Developer Group. When he's not coding Andrew is an avid film watcher.
akelly.name: Andrew Kelly

bduff.bio: Brian Duff cofounded and leads the Nearby team at Google. He's been on the Android team for the last four years, and hacking on Java in various forms since 1998. As well as being crazily into proximity and Android, Brian loves guitar, looking after his 3 and 4 year old, and singing his geeky heart out.
bduff.name: Brian Duff

bsills.bio: I am a Chicago-based Android developer working for Isobar, a digital marketing agency. Over the past few years, I've worked many projects for various clients, ranging from sports teams to fast food companies. I have presented a few small talks at local Android meetups. Outside of coding, I enjoy biking around the city, watching movies at my local theater, and going to concerts.
bsills.name: Bryan Sills

cchang.bio: I'm currently working on the Android team on June Oven, building the first truly smart oven to help anybody cook! Previously I worked at VSCO, helping build and support the Android app for over 5 million users. I've taught a few Android classes through organizations such as Women Who Code and also AP Computer Science for high school students.
cchang.name: Caren Chang

cguzman.bio: Originally a ruby on rails developer, Chris made the jump into Android a year ago. He started his dev career 2 years ago after teaching himself to code. Chris loves helping others learn and leads intro to code classes as wells as co-organizes the Baltimore Hackathon.
cguzman.name: Chris Guzman
cguzman.title: Developer Advocate

clee.bio: Christina is a Android developer at Pinterest. After launching the first version of the Pinterest video player on Android, she now works on a special initiatives team doing rapid prototyping for research and validation purposes.
clee.name: Christina Lee

dsmith.bio:
Dave Smith is a Developer Advocate for IoT at Google, focused on growing
developer support on the Android Things platform. Dave has been
working with the Android stack at all levels since 2009, developing
custom applications and system components to run Android on
embedded platforms or interact with external embedded
devices. He has a passion for making things smart, whether that be other
developers or devices.
dsmith.name: Dave Smith

dstevenson.bio: Doug is a Google Developer Advocate working with the Firebase team.  He's been doing Android development since 2008 with the release of the first Android device, the HTC G1.  Outside of work, Doug follows NHL hockey and enjoys craft beer.
dstevenson.name: Doug Stevenson

ecaron-petit-pas.bio:
Etienne is a software developer who’s worked on all tiers (server, web, mobile and embedded) of large scale software platforms. He is now a Mobile Dev Lead for Shopify, and is part of Google's Developer Expert program. 

Etienne got his start in programming in the mid-'80s obsessing over C64 demos, and went on to organize the NAID 95/96 demoparties. 3D animation, procedural content generation and VR are some of his hobbies, and he loves to introduce other developers to this fascinating field. He also regularly volunteers his time towards mentoring startups, developers and students in the mobile space. As part of the Montreal Android GDG, he organises meet-ups, hackathons, and gives regular talks on Android and VR-related subjects.

Previously, Etienne worked on projects ranging from high-availability stock trading software platforms, all the way to large scale municipal bike sharing systems (London’s cycle Hire amongst others). He lives in Montreal with his wife and daughter, and speaks French and English fluently.
ecaron-petit-pas.name: Etienne Caron-Petit-Pas

gkick.bio: Staff software engineer for Google.  Currently member of Google’s Java Core Libraries Team working on Dagger: dependency injection for Java and Android.  Former projects include Guava, Caliper, Google Takeout and Feedburner.
gkick.name: Gregory Kick
gkick.title: Staff Software Engineer

hdao.bio:
Huyen Tue Dao is an Android developer and Google Developer Expert, currently working on the Android team at Trello.

Huyen is co-creator of the "Android Dialogs" YouTube channel which features interviews with people in the Android community.

She lives in Denver, CO though is often found in the DC Metro area. When she is not up late programming, she is often found up late gaming (video, board, card, anything).
hdao.name: Huyen Tue Dao
hdao.title: Android Developer

hvisser.bio: Hugo is a software engineer who has worked on enterprise, desktop and mobile software products. Since the introduction of Android he has been steadily focussing on developing for Android only, resulting in his first app in 2009. Hugo has released several open source libraries and tools to help him and other developers build better software. He’s a Google Developer Expert for Android and one of the organizers of the Dutch Android User Group. With his company Little Robots, he focuses on smart use of Android in every possible way.
hvisser.name: Hugo  Visser

jhoford.bio: John works on Android Studio and ConstraintLayout at Google. He has worked previously on RenderScript, Vector Drawables, computed shadows and photo editor filters. Prior to joining Google, John was a principal engineer at GE Healthcare working on their image processing applications framework.
jhoford.name: John Hoford

jmaltz.bio: I'm an Android engineering building applications at as part of the diner growth team at Yelp Eat24.  Before that, I worked on Yelp's Android application as part of their diner growth team.  When I'm not having dreams  of little green robots, you can find me anxiously waiting for the next batch of interns so that I get to help more people become great developers.
jmaltz.name: Jonathan Maltz

jwilson.bio: Jesse works on Square Cash in Waterloo Canada. He's contributed to OkHttp, Retrofit, Dagger, and Guava.
jwilson.name: Jesse Wilson

mallison.bio:
Mark Allison is a GDE for Android and software engineer with over 30 years' experience. He is passionate about providing the user with the best possible experience. He has developed both server and client side, most commonly Android on the client side, but with also for iOS, HTML5, Symbian, and J2ME. Mark writes a technical blog (http://blog.stylingandroid.com) which focuses on Android UI/UX topics, but often covers more general Android development techniques. 

When not being geeky, Mark likes to unwind by hurling abuse at football referees, specifically those who are unkind to his beloved Watford FC with whom he holds a season ticket. He also has a deep love of the chilli pepper and consumes spicy food (his favourite being Indian) at every opportunity! Mark is happily married with a grown up step-daughter, and lives in Hertfordshire, UK.
mallison.name: Mark Allison
mallison.title: Owner / Developer

mperlak.bio:
My name is Mateusz (Mat) , I work for ContextMedia Health as senior software developer in android .My twelve years experience in the field range form image processing, backend high scalable server code to android and web front ends..
Currently, my team focus on educational platform for health care patients at point of care.
mperlak.name: Mateusz Perlak

mpotter.bio: I am an Android engineer working at Pinterest.  I focus on accessibility and app performance.  In my free time, I sing a capella and play soccer.
mpotter.name: Mallika Potter
mpotter.title: Software Engineer (Android)

nnarasimhan.bio:
Independent developer and solutions architect targeting the Mobile Web. Completed a PhD in Computer Eng., and worked at Motorola Research on mobile and ubiquitous computing solutions spanning automotive, television, smartphone and wearable platforms for 12 years. Currently work with early stage startups to build cross-platform mobile web product for consumers. 

Organize GDG chapters (NYC and Hudson Valley) and events (Android Camp, DevFest NYC). Currently interested in machine learning, internet of things and ubiquitous computing technology.
nnarasimhan.name: Nitya Narasimhan

nroard.bio: Nicolas worked over the years on various projects at Google, from the HTML5 support in Android Browser, implementing the webview hardware acceleration in Honeycomb, or writing a scalable and non-destructive photo editor in JB/KitKat. After a year building high-speed telemetry systems for robots, he came back to Android, developed ConstraintLayout and now works on the Android Studio layout editor.
nroard.name: Nicolas Roard

pbreault.bio: Philippe is a software engineer at American Express and has been passionate about android since 2010.He worked on a wide variety of Android apps for banks, newspapers, startups, television providers and more.He is a GDE (Google Developer Expert), one of founding organizers of droidcon Montréal and the author of the adb idea plugin for Android studio.
pbreault.name: Philippe Breault
pbreault.title: Senior Software Engineer

pshadlyn.bio:
I love Android even more than baseball.

I'm an Android development for VarageSale, a family-friendly app which lets you buy and sell new and used items locally.  I’m also the lead Android developer for Triplify, an Australian-based startup which tells you what’s going on wherever you are. In a past life I was a controls engineer, but I started working with Android during the Froyo days and have never looked back.

I've presented at a number of Android meetups and tech events, including giving a talk on Android Auto at the Square offices in Kitchener, Ontario, Canada.  

Here are some of my previous presentations:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeSKaz6PCm4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WNaJlP36I4E
https://speakerdeck.com/physphil
pshadlyn.name: Phil Shadlyn

rbhalla.bio: I'm a Google Expert for Design and a Partner at Uncommon, one of the leading design studios in India.
rbhalla.name: Raveesh Bhalla

vgonda.bio: Victoria is a software developer at Collective Idea, building mobile and web applications. She is passionate about using technology to help better the lives of individuals. Studying both Computer Science and Dance in college, she now enjoys digging into dance technology, and keeping up with dance classes in her spare time.
vgonda.name: Victoria Gonda

yprabhu.bio:
Yash Prabhu leads the Android team at DramaFever (a Warner Bros. company). She has spoken at several tech meetups and conferences over the past three years. In her spare time, she volunteers at Google Developers Group/Android Alliance Philadelphia as a teaching assistant, instructor, mentor and organizer

Jessica’s career began nearly a decade ago at Condé Nast and Firstborn, before joining Radical.Media as a multi-disciplinary designer focusing on film, packaging, digital & print.  From there, her career focused in ecommerce as a lead designer at Born Group. Throughout her career she has been able to work with brands including Grey Goose,Tommy Hilfiger, Bon Jovi, Sandro (US), Movado, Red Bull, Phaidon and Tag Heuer.  

In recent years, Jessica has tackled Product Design at a DramaFever, Warner Bros. owned video streaming service, catering to millions of viewers worldwide. She is continually honing and developing her craft through different mediums of digital design, staying atop her field.
yprabhu.name: Yash  Prabhu
